seed_text: A friend of mine taking psychology advised I go to my doctor to check if I have major depressive disorder. I'm afraid of the consequences of doing so. If I do become diagnosed with major depressive disorder, won’t that go on my records? I will never be able to become a counselor along with a list of other things I may be prohibited from. I’m also afraid of taking any anti-depressants. This year, my doctor gave me some for a "dislocated hip." I had a severe reaction and passed out moments after taking them. Everyone I know who has taken anti-depressants says it’s a bad idea all around and you’re better getting treatment without them. I’m concerned they might take me to a clinic and force me to take medication because I am unable to make decisions on my own. I’m not really suicidal, but I am not really taking care of myself either. Someone also told me they still use electroshock therapy. I’m not keen on that. I’m wondering if I am better off just getting self-help and working things out on my own. It’s just that I've been an emotional mess since I was in elementary school. I’ve graduated now and tried to stay positive and be happy, but I cannot deny I still am not good.

transcript.content: Hi, it’s really good to meet you. I appreciate you taking the step to reach out and start this process. Before we get into things, I want you to know that our sessions are confidential, and you are in control of what you want to share and the pace you want to go at. How are you feeling about being here today?

I’m a little nervous, to be honest. I’ve never done therapy before. I mostly just want to figure things out, but I’m worried about what might happen if I go to a doctor or get diagnosed with something like depression.

It’s completely normal to feel nervous, especially when you’re considering something new and potentially life-changing. I hear that you’re worried about the consequences of getting a diagnosis, particularly about it going on your records and affecting your future plans, like becoming a counselor. You’ve also had a tough experience with medication in the past, and you’ve heard some concerning things about antidepressants and treatments like electroshock therapy. Did I get that right?

Yes, exactly. I just don’t want anything permanent on my record that could stop me from helping others later. And I really don’t want to be forced to take meds, especially after what happened before. My friend meant well, but it scared me a bit.

Thank you for sharing all of that. Your concerns are very valid. It sounds like you really value your independence and your future career, and you want to make sure you’re not making things worse for yourself. Can you tell me a little about what’s been going on for you emotionally or day-to-day that made your friend suggest seeing someone?

I’ve just been feeling… off, for a long time. Since I was a kid really. I get sad a lot and it’s hard to stay motivated. I don’t really take care of myself the way I should, but I’m not suicidal. I just feel messy, like I’m not living up to who I should be. I try to be positive, but it’s hard.

That sounds very difficult, and it’s understandable that you’d want to feel better and more like yourself. You’ve been carrying these feelings for a long time, and it takes courage to talk about them. I’m here to support you in finding what works best for you—whether that’s self-help, therapy, or another approach. Before we go further, I want to check in with you about how you’d like our sessions to go. Some people prefer a more direct style, where I offer advice and suggestions. Others prefer a more reflective style, where I ask questions and help you explore your own thoughts and feelings. Do you have a preference for one style over the other, or would you like to try a mix?

I think I’d like you to be a bit more direct. I tend to go in circles if I’m left to just talk, so some advice or suggestions would help. But I don’t want to be pushed into anything, if that makes sense.

Absolutely, that makes perfect sense. I’ll aim to be more direct and offer guidance, but always at your pace and with your consent. We can adjust as we go, too. Before we wrap up today, could you share what you hope to get out of therapy, or what would make this feel worthwhile for you?

I guess I want to feel more in control of my mood and not so overwhelmed all the time. I want to be able to take care of myself better and maybe figure out if I really do have depression or if it’s just how I am. And I don’t want it to mess up my future if I do get help.

Thank you for sharing that. Those are important goals, and together we can work towards helping you feel more in control and supported without risking your future plans. If anything ever feels uncomfortable or not right for you, please let me know. I’m here to help you find what truly works for you.

Hi, it’s good to see you again. I appreciate you coming back. Last time, you mentioned feeling off for a long time—sad, unmotivated, and struggling to take care of yourself. You also said you’re not suicidal, but you feel messy and not living up to who you should be. I want to help you get a better handle on these feelings. Would it be okay if we talk a bit more today about what your day-to-day looks like and how these feelings show up for you?

Yeah, that’s fine. My days are kind of all over the place. I usually wake up feeling really tired, even if I slept enough. It takes me a while to get out of bed, and I usually skip breakfast. I’m in college, so I force myself to go to class, but it feels like I’m just going through the motions. I haven’t really been keeping up with assignments as well as I should. When I get home, I mostly just scroll on my phone or watch YouTube, and then I feel guilty for wasting time.

Thank you for describing your routine. It sounds like it’s tough to get started in the morning, and there’s a lot of guilt around how you spend your time after classes. Can I ask—have you noticed if these patterns have changed over time, or have you always struggled with motivation and energy like this?

I think it’s been this way for a long time, but it got worse after high school. I used to be better at keeping up with things, but now I just feel… heavy, like everything takes extra effort. There are days where I do better, but they don’t last. I try to set goals and make lists, but I usually don’t follow through.

That feeling of heaviness and struggling to follow through on plans is something a lot of people with depression describe. I know you’re not sure if what you’re experiencing is depression or just your personality. Would you be open to us exploring some of the signs together, to see if anything fits for you?
Yeah, I think that would help. I just don’t want to label myself if it’s not really that.

Absolutely, and we don’t have to put any labels on anything unless you’re comfortable. Let’s just look at some common symptoms. Besides the low motivation and heaviness, do you notice changes in your appetite, sleep, or interest in things you used to enjoy?

I guess my appetite is kind of up and down. Sometimes I forget to eat, and other times I snack a lot. I sleep a lot on weekends, but during the week I stay up too late. And yeah, I don’t really enjoy stuff I used to—like reading or drawing. I just can’t get into it.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you’re experiencing several symptoms that can be linked to depression, but it’s also understandable to feel unsure. I want to reassure you that just exploring these signs doesn’t commit you to any diagnosis or treatment. Right now, our focus is just on understanding what’s going on for you and figuring out practical steps to help you feel better. Would you be interested in trying some specific strategies this week, like setting one manageable self-care goal each day, to start shifting things a bit?
Yeah, that sounds doable. I think if it’s just one thing a day, I could try that. I just don’t want to feel like a failure if I can’t keep it up.

That’s a really important point. The goal isn’t to be perfect, but to experiment and notice what helps and what gets in the way. If you miss a day, it’s not failure—it’s just information we can use together. How about we start with something simple, like making sure you eat breakfast or go for a short walk? Which one feels more doable to you right now?
I think I could try eating breakfast. That seems manageable.

Great choice. Let’s keep it simple—maybe even just a granola bar or some toast. Next time, we can check in on how that felt and what you noticed. And if it doesn’t go as planned, that’s okay. We’ll figure it out together. Before we finish, is there anything else on your mind or anything you’d like more advice about this week?
I just want to know if it ever gets easier. I feel like I’ve been stuck for so long.

That’s a very honest question, and I’m glad you asked. It can get easier, especially with support and when you start making small, consistent changes. It might take time, but you’re not alone in this, and we’ll take it step by step. Let’s check in next time on how breakfast goes, and we’ll keep building from there. Thank you for your openness today.
Hi, it’s good to see you again. Last week, we talked about trying to eat breakfast each day as a small self-care goal. How did that go for you?
I actually managed to eat breakfast most days. It was just a granola bar or something simple, but I did it four out of seven days.
That’s a great start, especially since you said before that mornings are tough. How did you feel on the days you ate breakfast compared to the days you didn’t?

I think I felt a little less tired on those days, or maybe just less… empty. I still didn’t feel super motivated, but it was like I had done at least one thing right. On the days I skipped, I kind of fell back into old habits.

Noticing that difference is really important. Even a small win, like eating breakfast, can help shift your mindset a bit. You mentioned feeling less empty—does that surprise you at all, given how simple the change was?
Yeah, actually. I always thought I had to do something big to feel better, like totally fix my routines. But just doing one thing made a difference. I didn’t expect that.

That’s a really valuable insight. A lot of people underestimate the power of small, consistent changes. It sounds like you’re starting to see that caring for yourself doesn’t have to be all-or-nothing—it can be about building on small steps. How does it feel to realize that?
Honestly, it makes things feel a bit less overwhelming. Like maybe I don’t have to fix everything at once. Maybe I can just work on one thing at a time.

Exactly. Focusing on one manageable goal at a time can make things feel more doable and less discouraging. This week, would you like to keep working on breakfast, or is there another small self-care goal you’d like to try adding?
I want to keep the breakfast thing going, but maybe also try going outside for a few minutes each day. I think I could manage that.

That sounds like a great next step. Keeping breakfast as your foundation, and adding a short walk or just a few minutes outside, is a realistic way to build on your progress. Remember, if you miss a day, it doesn’t mean you failed—it just means you’re learning what works for you. How does that plan sound?
It actually sounds doable. I’m still nervous I’ll mess up, but last week showed me I can do more than I thought.

That’s a big realization. You’re proving to yourself that change is possible, even if it’s gradual. We’ll check in next time on how it goes, and adjust as needed. Before we finish, is there anything else you’d like to talk about or get advice on today?
No, I think that’s good for now. Thanks for helping me see it differently.
You’re very welcome. You’re doing important work, and I’m glad to support you. See you next week.
Hi, it’s good to see you again. Last time, you set the goal of continuing with breakfast and also spending a few minutes outside each day. How did things go for you this week?

Honestly, not great. I kind of fell off with both goals. I only ate breakfast once or twice, and I barely went outside at all. I just got busy with school and then kept forgetting, and by the end of the week I felt like I’d messed it all up. It feels like every time I try to change something, I end up back where I started.

Thank you for being so honest about that. Setbacks like this are actually a really normal part of making any kind of change, especially when life gets busy or stressful. I want to check in—when you realized you weren’t keeping up with your goals, what kinds of thoughts went through your mind?

Mostly just that I can’t stick to anything, so what’s the point? I know we talked about not being perfect, but it still feels like failing. And then I just stopped trying because I figured I’d already messed up the week.

It sounds like you’re being really hard on yourself, and that the all-or-nothing thinking is making it tougher to get back on track. That’s a common trap—feeling like if you miss a few days, you might as well give up. But the truth is, progress isn’t about being perfect. It’s about getting back up and trying again, even after setbacks. If you had a friend in your situation, would you judge them as harshly as you’re judging yourself right now?
No, I’d probably tell them it’s okay and not to give up. But it’s different when it’s me.

That’s such an important observation. It’s much easier to show compassion to others than to ourselves. One thing I want to suggest is treating these setbacks as information instead of proof that you can’t change. For example, was there anything specific that made it harder for you to stick to your goals this week—like a busy schedule, stress, or something else?
Yeah, I had a bunch of assignments and I was really stressed. I also just felt tired all the time, so even simple things felt like too much.

That makes a lot of sense. When stress and exhaustion build up, it’s normal for self-care to get harder. Instead of expecting yourself to do everything, it might help to scale back and focus on the smallest possible version of your goals. For example, if you can’t manage a full breakfast, maybe just drinking a glass of water counts. Or if going outside feels like too much, even opening a window or stepping onto your porch for one minute is a win. Would you be willing to try making your goals even smaller this week, so they feel more doable?
I think I could try that. I guess I didn’t realize I could make them that small and still count it.

Absolutely, it still counts. The goal is to build a sense of success and momentum, even with tiny steps. If you hit a rough patch, doing the smallest version of your goal still helps break the cycle of all-or-nothing thinking. Let’s set a plan: each day, just do the minimum—maybe eat or drink something in the morning, and if you can, get a breath of fresh air, even for a minute. If you do more, that’s great, but if not, the smallest effort still counts. How does that sound?
That actually sounds manageable. I think I can try that without feeling so much pressure.

I’m glad to hear that. Remember, setbacks don’t erase your progress—they’re just part of the process. If you notice yourself slipping into negative self-talk, try to pause and ask yourself what you’d say to a friend in the same position. We’ll check in next time on how this approach worked. Before we finish, is there anything else you want advice or support with today?
Not right now. I just hope I can actually stick to it this time.

You’re not alone in this, and every time you try again, you’re building resilience—even if the steps are small. We’ll keep finding what works for you, together. Thank you for sticking with it and for your honesty today.

Hi, welcome back. Last time, we talked about how setbacks can happen and how making your self-care goals as small as possible can help them feel more manageable. How did things go this past week with trying out those 'tiny steps'?

It went better, actually. I didn't do it every single day, but I did manage to drink some water most mornings and opened my window a couple of days, even if I didn’t go outside. It felt less overwhelming than before.

That’s really encouraging to hear. Even if it wasn’t every day, the fact that you did something—even something small—shows you’re making progress. Did you notice any difference in how you felt about yourself or your day when you managed those small steps?
Yeah, I think I felt a little less guilty. Like I was at least trying, even if it wasn't a big deal. It was easier to get started when the goal wasn't so huge.

That’s an important realization. A lot of people get stuck thinking they have to do everything perfectly, but when you lower the bar and allow small efforts to count, it becomes easier to keep going and you start to break that all-or-nothing cycle. That’s a real shift from where you were before.
Yeah, I guess I always thought if I couldn’t do the whole thing, it didn’t matter. But making it smaller made it feel okay to just do something.

Absolutely. And over time, those small efforts build up. One practical strategy is to remind yourself: 'something is always better than nothing.' Would it help to actually write that down somewhere as a reminder for tough days?
Yeah, I think seeing it written out would help when I start slipping into negative thinking.

Great. Let’s make that an explicit part of your plan for this week. Here’s what I suggest: Write the phrase 'Something is better than nothing' on a sticky note or somewhere visible. Each day, when you start your morning, look at it and do one tiny self-care action—like drinking a glass of water, eating a bite of breakfast, or opening your window. The goal is to use that phrase to interrupt the all-or-nothing thinking and remind yourself that small steps count.
That sounds clear. I’ll put it on my desk so I see it first thing. I can do at least one small thing each morning.

Perfect. To recap: Your task for this week is to write 'Something is better than nothing' where you’ll see it daily, and do one tiny self-care action each morning while reminding yourself that it counts. Next time, we’ll talk about how it felt to use that reminder and whether it helped with your motivation or self-talk. How does that plan feel to you?
I feel good about it. It feels doable and I like having something specific to look at when I get stuck.
I’m glad to hear that. You’ve made real progress in challenging those harsh expectations and finding what actually works for you. We’ll keep building on that. See you next week.

Hi, welcome back. Last week, you planned to put up a note saying 'Something is better than nothing' and do one small self-care action each morning while using that reminder. How did things go for you with that plan?

It was kind of weird this week. I put the sticky note on my desk, and I saw it every morning. Some days I did something, like drank water, but a couple of times I just stared at the note and felt annoyed, like I was forcing myself and it didn’t mean anything. Once I even took the note down for a day because it made me feel guilty for not doing the thing. I know it's supposed to help, but what if it just starts feeling like pressure instead of encouragement?

user_stated_goals_session1: Feel more in control of mood
Get help without jeopardizing future plans

generated_session5_outcome.key_insight_session5: Lowering self-care expectations to 'tiny steps' and using a visible reminder helps interrupt all-or-nothing thinking, making it easier to take action and reduce guilt.
generated_session5_outcome.agreed_task_for_session6: Write 'Something is better than nothing' where you can see it each morning, and do one tiny self-care action (like drinking water, eating a bite of breakfast, or opening your window) while reminding yourself that small steps count.

seed_text: A girl and I were madly in love. We dated for over a year and were even talking about marriage and future plans together. She moved away for school, and we attempted a long distance relationship. We eventually broke up. It's been a year now, and I still haven't lost my feelings for her. I still love her the same way I did. I've suffered from depression ever since the breakup and have been unable to connect with anyone else. It's damaging me and my life.

transcript.content: Hi, thank you for coming in today. I know starting therapy can be a big step. I want you to know that this is a safe space, and everything we talk about is confidential. To start, could you tell me a little bit about what brought you here today?

Sure. I went through a breakup about a year ago. I was really in love with this girl—we dated for over a year, and we used to talk about our future together, even marriage. She moved away for school, and we tried long distance, but it didn’t work out. Since then, I haven’t been able to move on. I still love her exactly the same, and it’s been really hard.
That sounds incredibly painful. It sounds like you shared a deep connection with her, and losing that has left you feeling stuck, is that right?

Yeah. I just feel like I can’t let go. I think about her all the time, and I haven’t been able to connect with anyone else since. I’ve been pretty depressed, honestly, and it’s starting to affect other parts of my life.

Thank you for being so open about how you’re feeling. It’s really understandable to feel this way after such a meaningful relationship, especially when you had plans for the future together. When you say it’s affecting other parts of your life, can you share a bit more about what that looks like for you?

Well, I’ve lost motivation for things I used to enjoy. My friendships have kind of faded because I don’t feel like hanging out with people. My work has suffered too. I just feel disconnected from everything.

It sounds like this loss has really impacted not just your emotions, but your daily life and routines, too. I want to support you in finding ways to heal and reconnect with yourself and others. To help me understand better, what do you hope to get out of therapy? Are there specific changes you’d like to see?

I just want to stop feeling this way. I want to be able to move on—to not think about her all the time, and to feel like myself again. I want to be happy and maybe be able to connect with someone new someday.

Those are really important goals. Wanting to feel happiness again and to rebuild connections with others are both very meaningful. Before we go further, I want to check in about how you’d like our sessions to go. Some people prefer a more direct, advice-oriented approach, where I give suggestions and strategies. Others prefer a reflective or questioning style, where I listen, ask questions, and help you explore your thoughts and feelings. Do you have a preference for how we work together?
I think I’d like a bit more direct advice. I feel like I’ve been stuck in my own head for too long, and I could use some concrete steps or suggestions.

Thank you for letting me know—that’s very helpful. I’ll make sure to provide more guidance and practical suggestions as we move forward, while also making space to hear what you’re experiencing. How does that sound?
That sounds good. I appreciate it.
Hi, it’s good to see you again. How have you been feeling since our last session?
Honestly, not much has changed. The last week was rough—there were a couple of days where I just really missed her. I kept thinking about reaching out, but I didn’t.

That sounds really tough, but I want to acknowledge that you didn’t reach out, even though you felt the urge. That’s a big step. Can you tell me more about what was going through your mind on those days?

Mostly I kept replaying old memories. Like, I’d see something that reminded me of her or catch myself wanting to tell her about my day. I just felt this emptiness. Sometimes I wonder if I’ll ever feel that close to someone again.

It sounds like those memories are still very vivid for you, and they bring up a lot of longing. When you think about her or the relationship, are there certain moments or feelings that stand out the most?
Yeah. I keep thinking about this weekend trip we took to the coast. It felt perfect. We laughed a lot, talked about our future. I felt really understood by her—like I could be myself.
That sense of being understood and accepted sounds really important to you. Since the breakup, have you been able to experience that feeling of being accepted or understood, with anyone else?
Not really. I have friends, but it’s not the same. I haven’t really opened up to them, to be honest. I guess I just keep things on the surface.

It makes sense that after a loss like this, you might feel guarded or less motivated to open up to others. Sometimes people worry that they won’t find that kind of connection again, or that something about them is preventing it. Do any of those thoughts sound familiar to you?
Yeah, I do worry about that. I wonder if maybe I messed things up, or if I’m just not good at relationships. I haven’t even tried dating again—I don’t think I’m ready.

Those doubts are really common, and they can make it feel even harder to move forward. I want to offer a few concrete steps we can work on, if you’re open to it. First, would you be willing to try reconnecting with a friend or two this week, just for a low-pressure hangout or conversation? Not to talk about the breakup—just to start rebuilding some connection.
I could try. I haven’t been great about responding to people, but maybe I could reach out to one of my friends from work.

That sounds like a good start. Sometimes just taking a small step toward reconnecting can make a difference. Another idea: when you notice yourself getting caught up in those memories or urges to reach out to your ex, try writing down what you’re feeling in that moment—just for yourself. It can help create some space between the feeling and the action, and give you a chance to reflect.
Okay, I can do that. I’ve never really tried journaling, but I’ll give it a shot.
Great. We can check in about how that goes next time. Before we wrap up, is there anything else that’s been on your mind, or any questions about what we discussed today?
I guess I just want to know if this feeling will ever go away. Sometimes it feels permanent.

I hear how heavy that feels. The pain from a loss like this can feel overwhelming, but with time and support, it does get easier. The steps we’re taking are part of that process. Let’s keep working together on this, and remember, you don’t have to go through it alone.
Hi, welcome back. Before we check in about the past week, I want to thank you for your commitment to this process. How have things been since our last session?

It's been a little up and down. I tried reaching out to my friend from work like we talked about. We got coffee after our shift, and it was actually nice. I still felt kind of disconnected, but it was better than just being alone.
That’s a great step. Even though it felt a bit disconnected, you made the effort and followed through. Did anything stand out to you during that time together?

I realized that when we were talking, I kept wanting to mention my ex or bring up the breakup, but I stopped myself. I think I’m used to thinking about her all the time, so it’s hard to focus on other stuff.
It sounds like your mind is almost on autopilot—defaulting to thoughts about your ex. That’s normal after a significant loss. Did you try the journaling exercise when those thoughts came up?

Yeah, I did. A couple times, actually. At first it just felt weird, but by the second time, I noticed that writing it down made the feeling less intense. Like, once I saw the words on paper, it was almost like I could get a little distance from it.
That’s an important observation. Sometimes putting our feelings into words helps us step back and see them more clearly. Did you notice anything else when you looked back at what you wrote?

I noticed that a lot of my thoughts are about things I miss, but also about things I’m afraid of—like never feeling that way again or being alone. It’s not just about her, it’s about what I lost and what I’m scared of.

That’s a really valuable insight. It’s not only the loss of the relationship, but also fears about your future and your sense of connection. Understanding that can help us focus on both processing the loss and rebuilding your sense of hope. How does it feel to recognize that?
Honestly, I hadn’t thought about it that way before. I always just thought I missed her, but maybe I’m more afraid of not having that kind of connection again.

That’s a big realization. When we focus only on the person, it’s easy to feel stuck. But when we realize it’s also about our deeper needs and fears, it opens up new ways to heal. One direct step we can take is to start exploring what makes you feel connected—not just with one person, but in other areas of your life. Would you be open to thinking about activities or situations where you’ve ever felt that sense of belonging or meaning, even if it wasn’t with your ex?
I can try. I think maybe when I’m out hiking or with a group at work, sometimes I feel a little bit of that. I can pay more attention to it this week.

That’s a good plan. Keep journaling about those moments—what you notice, even small glimpses of connection or meaning. Next time, we’ll look at ways to build on them. Is there anything else you want to talk about today?
No, I think that’s enough for now. Thanks for helping me see it differently.
You’re welcome. I’m glad you’re noticing these things, and I look forward to hearing what you discover this week.
Hi, it’s good to see you again. Before we check in about last week’s goals, is there anything on your mind that you’d like to start with today?

Actually, yeah. I had a rough week. I know I was supposed to pay attention to moments of connection or meaning, but honestly, I just felt worse. My ex posted a picture with someone new and it just... I felt like I was back at square one. Since then, I haven’t really wanted to do anything. I’m frustrated with myself for not making any real progress.

That sounds really painful, and I can see why it would feel like a setback. Seeing your ex move on brings up a lot of emotions—sometimes it can feel like everything you’ve worked on just falls apart in that moment. I want to reassure you: setbacks are a normal part of healing, and they don’t erase the progress you’ve made.

I guess. It just feels like if I can get knocked down that fast, maybe I’m not actually getting better. Like I’m just pretending. I even thought about messaging her again, just to say hi, but I didn’t. I just feel stuck and kind of hopeless.

It’s completely understandable to feel stuck and hopeless when something triggers those old feelings so strongly. The fact that you didn’t reach out, even though you wanted to, tells me you’re using some of the tools we talked about. That’s real progress, even if it doesn’t feel like it right now.
Maybe. It just feels exhausting. I keep thinking, what’s the point if I’m always going to feel this way when something comes up? I don’t know how long I can keep doing this.

That exhaustion is real, and it’s a sign that you’ve been working hard at this—even if it doesn’t show up as big changes yet. Here’s a direct suggestion: instead of aiming to feel better all the time, let’s focus on building resilience for these tough moments. That means having a plan for what to do when you get triggered, like when you see something about your ex. Would you be willing to try creating a quick action plan for those moments, so you have something to turn to when the feelings hit?
I can try. What would that look like?

Here’s a simple version: when you get triggered, first, notice and name what you’re feeling—like 'I’m feeling hurt and left behind.' Then, take three deep breaths to ground yourself. Next, do something that interrupts the spiral—go for a walk, text a friend (it doesn’t have to be about your ex), or write down what you’re thinking. The goal isn’t to make the pain disappear, but to give yourself some control and prevent old patterns, like reaching out to your ex or isolating.
I guess that makes sense. I can write it down and keep it in my phone or something. I just hope it actually helps when I feel that way.

It might not work perfectly every time, but having a plan is a powerful step. Over time, these moments will get easier to handle. Also, it’s okay to be frustrated—healing isn’t a straight line. We’ll keep working together, even when it’s hard. For this week, try using your action plan when those feelings come up, and keep journaling about how it goes. We’ll review it together next time.
Alright. I’ll give it a shot. Thanks for being straight with me.
You’re welcome. I appreciate your honesty and determination, even when things feel rough. We’ll get through this together, one step at a time.
Hi, welcome back. I appreciate you coming in, especially after a tough week. Before we dive in, how have you been feeling since our last session?

It’s been up and down, honestly. After seeing that photo of my ex, I felt pretty awful for a couple days. But I did try to use the action plan we talked about. It didn’t make the feelings go away, but I guess it helped me not spiral as much.
That’s an important step. The goal isn’t to erase the pain, but to help you manage it so it doesn’t take over. Can you walk me through what you did when you noticed those feelings come up?

Sure. I was scrolling on my phone when I saw the photo, and right away I felt that old gut punch. I remembered to pause and told myself, 'I’m feeling jealous and sad.' I took a few deep breaths, but then I just wanted to lie on my bed. I forced myself to go for a walk instead, just around the block. It distracted me a little. Later, I wrote about what happened in my journal.

You used several parts of the plan—naming your feelings, grounding with your breath, interrupting the spiral with a walk, and then journaling afterward. That’s a lot to put into practice during a tough moment. How did things feel after you did those steps?

Honestly, I still felt sad, but less out of control. The urge to message her faded a bit after the walk, and writing it down made the whole thing seem a little less overwhelming. I guess it gave me something to do other than just sit in it.

That’s exactly the point of the plan—not to erase your feelings, but to give you back some control when things hit hard. You’re building resilience, not numbness. Did you notice any patterns when you looked back at your journal entries?
Yeah, actually. Every time I get triggered, it’s not just missing her—it’s feeling left behind, or like everyone else is moving on except me. Seeing her with someone new really brought that up.

That’s a really key insight. The pain is about more than your ex—it’s about feeling stuck, or like you’re falling behind in life. Recognizing that helps us target the real pain points. Instead of only focusing on the relationship, we can also work on building your sense of progress and self-worth, no matter what your ex is doing.
Yeah, that makes sense. I think I focus so much on her because it feels like proof that I’m not moving forward. I want to feel like I am.

Let’s build on that. Here’s a direct, actionable step for this week: Each day, I want you to write down one thing—no matter how small—that you did for yourself that shows you’re moving forward or taking care of yourself. It could be anything: responding to a friend, going for a walk, using your action plan, even getting out of bed on a hard day. The point is to collect evidence of your own progress, independent of your ex.
Okay, I can do that. Just one thing a day, right? Even if it’s something small?

Exactly. The goal is to shift your focus from what you feel you’ve lost to the steps you’re taking, even the tiny ones. We’ll review your list next session and talk about what you notice. Does that feel manageable?
Yeah, that’s doable. I think it might help me see things differently.
Great. So we’re agreed—each day, you’ll write down one specific thing you did that shows movement or self-care, no matter how small. We’ll check in about it next week.
Hi, welcome back. Last time we agreed you’d keep a daily list of things you did to take care of yourself or move forward. How did that go for you this week?

I started the list and was pretty good about it for the first few days. But then something happened—I got a message from my ex out of nowhere. She just asked how I was doing. I ended up responding, and we talked a bit. After that, I felt like I ruined my progress, so I stopped writing things down for the rest of the week. I’m not sure if talking to her counts as moving forward or if I just set myself back.

user_stated_goals_session1: stop thinking about ex-partner all the time
be able to connect with someone new
